subject: Re: [junit] How to test focus without displaying the component
msgSnippet: ... I think there s a way of doing it if you re using Linux (or you could use for testing only, as it s java you re dealing with!). There s a thing called the
messageBody:
Timothy Wall wrote:
>
> There is no sensible way to test focus on a component without the
> component actually being "showing" since that is a fundamental part of
> the concept of focus, at least implicitly (the implementation usually
> removes components from focus consideration that are not actively
> participating in the current GUI, i.e. are not showing).
>
> T.
I think there's a way of doing it if you're using Linux (or you could
use for testing only, as it's java you're dealing with!).
There's a thing called the virtual framebuffer X server, here's it's
description:
xvfb provides an X server that can run on machines with no display
hardware and no physical input devices. It emulates a dumb framebuffer
using virtual memory. The primary use of this server was intended to be
server testing, but other novel uses for it have been found, including
testing clients against unusual depths and screen configurations, doing
batch processing with Xvfb as a background rendering engine, load
testing, as an aid to porting the X server to a new platform, and
providing an unobtrusive way to run applications that don't really need
an X server but insist on having one anyway.

Hope it helps!

Regards,
Reda
